Name * Leslie BrunfeltAddress 1714 Fern AvenueDuluth, US-0-MN 55811United StatesPhone Number (218) 728-9932Email leslie9932@gmail.comProvide the docket's number. 24-198Leave a comment on the docket. *Private equity firms are focused on profit not on serving the public. They make promises innegotiations that are often not enforceable like keeping the headquarters in Duluth. They are knownto acquire a company in order to grow their own portfolios and cash flow relying heavily on debt,cost cutting, and raising costs to the consumers. They have investors interests first and foremost,not the consumer or the environment. It is a mistake to hand over this public company to this kindof private equity firm particularly in this environment of loosening regulations at the federal level.

From: Sue IsernhagenTo: Staff, CAO (PUC)Subject: Allete should not be acquired by BlackRockDate: Tuesday, April 8, 2025 11:44:15 AM

Dear CommissionI am very concerned about a large public entity which has served Northern Minnesota andbeyond very well.   It has always been a company that valued and served local interests and itsclients. KThe acquisition by a fund such as BlackWater is very dangerous and can derail the excellentpublic service Allete has started. It is realized Allete is a business and must be aware of futureplans. But this acquisition would take the backbone of services for Northern MN and bringthem to a group who has no local ties.   And also could sell off.  The US is losing control of its own infrastructure to foreign or business-first investorsPlease do not vote for this acquisition. Thank youSusan J IsernhagenDuluth MN

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Bonnie Beckel
Minneapolis, MN 55407-2440
beckelbonnie@gmail.com

Northern Minnesota residents will not benefit from private equity sale of Allete/MN Power to
Blackrock. We are already dealing with constant rate increases, and we don't need capital investorsor billionaires controlling any more of our public infrastructure than they already do. Selling toBlackrock will increase cost of living and make the region less competitive for businesses, as it willsignificantly affect costs for manufacturing and other industries in our region. There is no publicbenefit for selling this company to Blackrock, and many public disadvantages.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
We all know what happens with private equity organizations buy property: they underfund it, doing anything to
create a profit. Minnesotans deserve BETTER!
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical publicservice- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Carol OrbanEly, MN 55731-1236carolorban46@gmail.com

I am a Masters of Social Work Student in Duluth and am writing from my desire to live in Duluth for
the rest of my life, practicing therapy once I get my Clinical License. I am here to help people healand process the emotions and difficult events of life.I am writing to express my dissent and concern around the proposed acquisition of Minnesota Powerby BlackRock; it is not in the public’s interest and I’m asking the Public Utilities Commission to denythe proposal.
Private equity investors demand higher profits than normal market investors. We can see that
BlackRock does not put people over profit, because they play a large part in, and profit off thedeforestation of the Amazon Rainforest.We can also look to other places where acquisitions of this type have occurred… One utility in Texastaken over by private equity went bankrupt, another owned by private equity in Michigan has muchhigher residential rates than the neighboring co-op utilities also serving Michigan’s UP. 
I also feel concerned about the conflict of interest with Blackrock’s commitment to spending 100
Billion dollars in AI Data centers throughout the world, and how these data centers are beingproposed in Minnesota as of recently. It is not farfetched to believe that BlackRock wants to acquireMN Power to further profit off AI data centers at the expense of the rate-payer.
Please do not let BlackRock to acquire Minnesota Power

it, and whether our communities and climate commitments are protected. 
Private equity firms exist to maximize profit- not serve the public.Docket Number: 24-198Public hearings have started, and my voice matters.

I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action

Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
While regulated utilities like Minnesota Power are guaranteed a profit when they build or expand infrastructure (like
building a new gas plant), they don’t make money on “operational” costs, like maintenance and customer service.Investors looking for a high rate of return aren’t incentivized to maximize the things that make their service safe andreliable, meaning customers would face deteriorating service reducing reliability. The new owners have much highertarget profits than the normal rate of return for a Minnesota utility, and need to extract that value from the companysomehow – cutting unprofitable activities would support this goal.

- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service

state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).

Your honor,
My name is Megan Perry-Spears.  I am a ratepayer in Duluth and I strongly oppose
this transaction which will negatively impact my family and neighbors and the futurestability of the northland of Minnesota. I urge you to deny approval. 
I want to remind you that the MN Public Utilities commission can not approve thisproposed acquisition unless it makes findings that it is in the public interest in order toapprove it. It is not.  Minnesota Power has not demonstrated the need for the
proposed acquisition or any benefit to the people of the Northland.  –To be clear, thisis not in the public interest and I urge the Commission to deny the proposal, as thelaw requires.
Blackrock is already embedded in the energy industry–especially by way of
companies that have a history of harming the water and environment. To approve theproposal would be to create a huge conflict of interest. Blackrock’ is the single largestshareholder of Enbridge Energy. Enbridge is one of Minnesota Power’s pipelinecustomers. CPP is a major investor in resource extraction companies in Canada,including oil and gas drillers and Enbridge. 
These conflicts of interest become super problematic when you look at the profit
expectations of private equity firms like Blackrock. This proposed acquisition is likelyto raise rates for customers, because private equity investors demand higher profitsthan normal market investors. Over and over and over again in these kinds ofacquisitions the cost of the demanded profits gets passed on to the consumer. Privateequity wants the most profit in the relative short term, which is NOT good for thenorthland.  Blackrock most likely will go for high profit infrastructure investment ratherthan what is best for the people and the environment.  
I am worried about this for my kids.  Not only will they face the higher rates, they will
be left holding the bag environmentally.  Low cost solar and wind resources likely willnot align with the profit motive of private equity that will always choose maximizing
profits in the short term, before the ownership term is up. 
Speaking of the ownership term, when private equity firms have raised the rates and
squeezed all the short-term profit they can at the expense of the people and the land,they will sell the system off to the highest bidder, likely to other private equity, makingit impossible for public bidders to make a competitive bid. If you allow this sale, that iswhat will happen.  GIP and CPP will take control of the ALLETE Board of Directors.This is a threat to local control, as they will seek influence of Minnesota Power’sbusiness plans, budget, investments and corporate strategy.  
My neighbors here in Duluth cannot afford to pay rising rates to fill the pockets of
private equity billionaires. My children cannot afford the impact on the environment. GIP and CPP say they share the goal of transitioning to clean energy, but they will notcommit to things like retiring the Boswell coal plant on schedule. We know they willhave a conflict of energy in the extraction of oil and gas and  the pipeline industry. We don’t need a billionaire monopoly in our region controlling something so importantas our power.
For the sake of Minnesota, for the sake of the people, for the sake of my children and
your children, vote no. This sale is not in the best interest of the people. 
Thank you, 
Megan Perry-SpearsDuluth Resident-- Megan Perry-Spears

To Whom It Concerns,
I am a Duluth, MN resident/homeowner. I am alarmed to learn of the proposed sale of MN
Power, by Allete, to the joint venture of the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) andGlobal Infrastructure Partners (GIP). A significant portion of my concern lies in theknowledge that GIP is owned by BlackRock, the world’s largest private equity investmentfirm. 
As a private equity company, BlackRock's only goal is to generate profit for their
shareholders. They currently manage assets that exceed the GDP of most nations in the world. They could care less about the future viability of a relatively small utility company.  So theirinterest in this purchase is suspect, in my opinion. Purchasing our local utility under the guiseof CIP seems underhanded to me; and it is also clear in my mind that the customers who relyon fair pricing and good service from MN Power will be of little concern for this group.  
I have read that the buyers have offered to pay between $393 million and $1.5 billion above
MN Power's actual value. This would obviously be a windfall for ALLETE shareholders;however, the buyers will expect to recoup their investment through profits.  Such an over-inflated purchase price will create a challenging situation for CPP & GIP to recoup theirinvestment through generated profit. The customers of MN Power will be penalized in thissale with rate increases and diminished service. If the purchasers are unable to profit in thispurchase, it is likely our local utility service will be sold again ... further diminishing anyvested interest in our region. 
BlackRock has a reputation that disregards environmental concerns, such as solar and wind-
generated power.  They are a known large investor in the oil industry.  I do not see how theirpurchase of our local utility will benefit our region.  They are purely profit-driven and have noconcern as to the damage they leave on local regions or economies, when they decide to moveon. 
As a proud Minnesotan concerned about global climate change and equity issues that are
facing our world, and as a lifelong customer of MN Power, it breaks my heart to think that ourlocally owned utility will go the way of capitulation to billionaires. 
I respectfully implore the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission to deny this sale.Respectfully yours,Rebecca G. Lindquist

Duluth, MN 55803

Hello,
My name is Alice Lesch and I work a lot in central and northern Minnesota and have
developed meaningful relationships with the people there. I am expressing my concernregarding the proposed acquisition of Minnesota Power/ALLETE by the Canada Pension PlanInvestment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners/BlackRock.
Despite my extensive work in the area, I have not heard about this potential purchase until
today. Thanks to the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, I was informed that I can and shouldsubmit a comment if I am concerned. 
I am particularly concerned regarding the proposed purchaser. I do not feel comfortable
allowing a large Minnesota-based business to be purchased by BlackRock. Minnesotamust not compromise our democratic structure despite the current political climate whichfavors gross corporate greed and influence in state and federal government. Especially in thecase of a utility where the economies of scale are so large to enter the industry that thegovernment needs to accommodate these monopolies just to serve their constituents withpower. The following is a quote from the Citizens Utility Board which states this issue veryconcisely: 
"The buyers have agreed to buy ALLETE at a substantial premium. They will want to make
back their investment. 
Expert witnesses in the case have estimated that the buyers have offered to pay between $393million and $1.5 billion above the company’s actual value. This is a windfall for ALLETEshareholders that the buyers will expect to recoup, with profits.  
While ALLETE holds multiple businesses, regulated utilities make up the majority of its
revenue (81% in 2024). It will be difficult, if not impossible, for the new owners to make backthe purchase premium without leaning on ratepayers, which could lead to rate increases forMinnesota Power customers.
Of course, Minnesota Power’s rates must be approved by the PUC, and the company will
continue to have to justify any rate increases. However, if the PUC denies the rate increasesthat Minnesota Power’s new owners want, the owners may decide it is not in their interest toinvest much more money in the company, to the detriment of the quality of service thatMinnesotans receive."
Thank you for taking your time to read my comment.
Alice Lesch
